page.title: 09The Wallops
page.content: Wallop is a small village in Hampshire. In old Engish "Waella" means stream, and "hop" means valley. Now the two villages are called Over Wallop and Nether Wallop, but in the past they were called Wollop Inferior and Wollop Superior. Wallop Brook starts in a field opposite Pound Road. It goes down through Over Wallop and Nether Wallop, through Broughton, into Romsey and there it joins the River Test which flows down to Southampton and into the sea. Over Wallop was mentioned in the Domesday Book in 1085.There was enough land for one plough.There were two villages and two farms.The villages today have three churchs,three village shops, one petrol station, three pubs, a nursing home and one post office.The rest are mostly houses, some are thatched and some are tiled.
